comment._content:
This refreshment room and the one at Yass Jn had been closed before 1957.
Harden was the operational junction for the cross-country line via the important towns Young and Cowra, so the room would have been useful for those changing train.
From Sydney, rooms were spaced about 1-1.5 h apart.
Moss Vale: an important breakfast and supper stop for Melbourne trains until 1962, when the advent of through sg resulted in new trains, with onboard refreshments.  Moss Vale was closed.
Goulburn: People changing, and the through minor Canberra service (the major had onboard refreshments).  Later it was a supper stop for holiday-extra Melbourne trains, and an occasional breakfast stop.
Yass Jn: so minor that it was closed early on.
Harden: likewise.
Cootamundra: an important breakfast and supper stop for people connecting to branchlines.  It has been remodelled, and is still convenient for people changing from train to many radiating bus services there.
Junee: likewise.  It was also the changeover point for onboard crews, who stayed in the bedrooms on the second floor.  It has survived as a general-public tourist facility.
Wagga Wagga: May have had a minor one, but certainly gone by 1957.
Albury: In the days of break of gauge, it would have some breakfast & supper use, certainly at holiday times.  It wasn't a grand room originally: it was expanded in several stages by taking over a verandah, and a lamp room, with a bit of new construction filling the gap.

Roderick B Smith
Rail News Victoria Editor
